chapter.htmlHeader: How do I assess a person who may have gout?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Ask about:
    • Current and previous attacks:
      • Which joints are (and have been) involved. Gout typically affects the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe) — this is the case in 56-78% of people at first presentation. It is also common in the midfoot, ankle, knee, fingers, wrist and elbow joints although can effect any joint. Gout is usually monoarticular but can be oligoarticular or rarely polyarticular. 
      • Symptoms and rapidity of onset — severe pain with associated swelling, redness, warmth and tenderness usually reaches maximum intensity within 24 hours.
      • The frequency and duration of attacks.
      • Any previous drug interventions tried.
      • Ability to mobilize and impact on work and functioning.
    • Age of onset:
      • Onset of gout in a person younger than 30 years of age suggests renal or enzymatic disorders and is often associated with genetic causes. More aggressive investigation and drug treatment may be necessary.
      • Gout in the elderly sometimes presents atypically with an insidious onset and polyarticular involvement. Tophi can occur early in the disease (sometimes without previous attacks of gout). Postmenopausal women often initially present with hand small-joint tophi.
    • Possible risk factors and secondary causes for developing gout:
      • Alcohol intake.
      • Dietary intake of purines, particularly from red meat and seafood, and high intake of fructose, particularly sugary drinks.
      • Use of drugs that can raise plasma urate levels, such as ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, ciclosporin, diuretics, pyrazinamide, ritanovir, tacrolimus, and lead exposure.
      • Family history of gout, hyperuricaemia, nephrolithiasis or renal disease — family history of gout is common. A family history of gout at a young age suggests that a rarer genetic defect may be responsible.
    • Associated comorbidity which can increase the risk of developing gout or hyperuricaemia, including the following:
      • Obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidaemia (especially hypertriglyceridaemia), diabetes mellitus, congestive cardiac failure, ischaemic heart disease, chronic kidney disease, osteoarthritis, myeloproliferative disease, severe psoriasis, sickle cell anaemia, glycogen storage diseases, history of renal colic or nephrolithiasis.
  • Look for evidence of:
    • Arthritis (swelling, redness, warmth, and pain on passive movement), typically of the first metatarsophalangeal joint, although any joint can be affected.
      • Lower limb joints are affected more frequently than upper limb joints.
      • Examine all joints to assess for subtle signs in other joints.
      • If septic arthritis is suspected, refer for emergency joint aspiration and culture.
    • Tophi (firm, white nodules under translucent skin).
      • It usually takes at least 10 years after the first attack of acute gout for tophi to develop, although in atypical cases, tophaceous disease can be the initial presentation without any flares.
      • Tophi usually occur over extensor joint aspects such as the elbow or knee, or achilles tendon. They can occur in other areas such as the helix of the ears or dorsum of hands or feet.
      • They are usually pain-free but can become inflamed, infected or ulcerated, or discharge white material.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the American College of Rheumatology criteria for the diagnosis of acute gouty arthritis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The 'gold standard' for diagnosing gout is demonstration by microscopy of urate crystals in synovial fluid or tophi. However, testing for urate crystals in joint fluid or tophi is often not practical. 
  • In 2015, the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) and European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) published updated classification criteria for the gout. The criteria are classification rather than diagnostic criteria, designed for research purposes and are not specifically for use in clinical practice.

[BMJ Best Practice, 2017; Neogi, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • The recommendations on what to ask when taking a history and performing an examination in a person with suspected gout are based on expert opinion from review articles [Rott and Agudelo, 2003; Terkeltaub, 2003; Nuki, 2006; Roddy, 2013; Dalbeth, 2016], a BMJ Best Practice review [BMJ Best Practice, 2017] and a textbook [Warrell, 2010].
